choices.C: SELECT * FROM customers WHERE insert_date - DATE '2019-01-01';

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about CURRENT_TIMESTAMP? (Choose two.)

choices.E: The time is in the time zone of DBTIMEZONE.
choices.C: The date is in the time zone of DBTIMEZONE.
choices.D: It returns the same date as CURRENT_TIME.
choices.B: It returns a value of data type TIMESTAMP.
choices.A: The value varies depending on the setting of SESSIONTIMEZONE.
choices.F: It always returns the same value as SYSTEMTIMESTAMP.

discussion.content:
A & B are correct! 
C & E are incorrect because CURRENT_TIMESTAMP reflects the session time zone, not
DBTIMEZONE

Selected Answer: AB
AB should be the correct answer

Selected Answer: AB
A seems 100%. B is correct if you consider timestamp as the overarching data type of timestamp with time zone and timestamp with local time zone. However if D says current_date then I like AD over AB.

Selected Answer: AD
A - Is correct
D - Should be either CURRENT_TIMESTAMP or CURRENT_DATE

comments.content: Checked on my own, got the same conclusions. Not sure which ones are correct then

questions.question_text: Which two are true about using the FOR UPDATE clause in a SELECT statement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
BE is correct

Selected Answer: BE
B E are correct

comments.content: My bad, the alternative says CANNOT I mistakenly read CAN. Sorry.

B is WRONG

From Oracle SQL Reference:
Restrictions on the FOR UPDATE Clause
This clause is subject to the following restrictions:
• You cannot specify this clause with the following other constructs: the DISTINCT operator, CURSOR expression, set operators, group_by_clause, or aggregate functions.

BE are correct. 
C - FALSE. NOWAIT will not acquire locks from their owning transactions, but will not wait until they are released. If rows are already locked by other transaction (e.g. by UPDATE), then with NOWAIT parameter the ORA-00054 error will be thrown.

discussion.content: B - can SELECT FOR UPDATE be used with DISTINCT? I receive ORA-01786 error when testing

choices.A: It can be used with SET operators (UNION, INTERSECT etc.).
choices.D: The statement skips rows locked by other transactions.
choices.E: It can be used with joins.
choices.B: It cannot be used with the DISTINCT keyword.
choices.C: If the NOWAIT clause is added, the statement will automatically acquire locks from their owning transactions and not wait.

questions.question_text:
You must find the number of employees whose salary is lower than employee 110.

Which statement fails to do this?

discussion.content: fail A - because in the subquery exist condition referenced to main table but not subquery table. By other words, in the subquery not exist limitation for fetching rows and subquery return more than one row
A is not correct, failed with "ORA-01427: single-row subquery returns more than one row"

A -failed with "ORA-01427: single-row subquery returns more than one row"
